title: Lateral Ankle Sprain in a Recreational Tennis Player
clinical_history: Mr. James Turner is a 34-year-old recreational tennis player who sustained a right ankle injury 3 days ago during a doubles match. While reaching for a wide shot, he landed awkwardly on the lateral edge of his right foot, experiencing an immediate rolling sensation and a 'pop.' He was unable to continue playing and noted swelling on the lateral aspect of the ankle within 30 minutes. He has been managing with rest, ice, compression, and elevation since the incident. He reports ongoing pain and difficulty weight-bearing, especially during the first steps on waking and when climbing stairs. There is no history of previous significant ankle injuries. Mr. Turner is otherwise healthy and trains recreationally 2-3 times a week.

nprs.affected_area: lateral aspect of right ankle (anterior talofibular ligament region, peroneal muscle group)
dorsolateral foot (secondary due to compensatory gait, mild ache)

aggrevating_factors: weight-bearing activities (walking, especially on uneven ground), stair climbing, side stepping, twisting motions, and running.
picture: [insert image of right foot with swelling and bruising over the lateral malleolus]
easing_factors: rest, elevation, use of ice packs, and mild compression. Avoiding weight-bearing reduces pain significantly.
past_history: No significant previous ankle injuries; mild right knee pain after long tennis matches in the past, not currently symptomatic.
medical_history: No chronic medical conditions. No allergies. No previous surgeries.
medications: Occasional ibuprofen (up to 400 mg twice daily over the past 3 days) for pain and swelling.
personal_history: Works as a software engineer. Non-smoker, social alcohol use. Enjoys recreational sports, including tennis and hiking. Lives with his partner; no children.
imaging: No imaging done to date; Ottawa Ankle Rules suggest no fracture risk, but swelling and ecchymosis noted around the lateral malleolus on examination.
